description: {"blocks":[{"key":"aqp7e","text":"Over the past two decades, transcriptional profiling has become an increasingly common tool for investigating the effects of diseases and experimental manipulations on the nervous system. Within transcriptional profiling experiments, microarray or sequencing technologies are used to measure the relative amount of RNA transcript for each of the thousands of genes expressed in a sample. The primary objective of these experiments is to identify genes that are differentially expressed in response to conditions of interest. However, transcriptional profiling experiments have traditionally been conducted with small sample sizes due to expense (e.g., n=3-10/group), resulting in low statistical power. Due to low power, these experiments are prone to capturing large technical artifacts and false positives rather than smaller biological effects of interest.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1etn8","text":"To address this issue, we developed a 10-week summer research program (The Brain Data Alchemy Project) that guides participants through the process of performing a meta-analysis of differential expression effect sizes (Log2 Fold Change or Log2FC) extracted from publicly available transcriptional profiling datasets. To conduct our meta-analyses, we leverage the efforts of the Gemma project, which has curated, preprocessed, and re-analyzed over 19,000 publicly available datasets (https://gemma.msl.ubc.ca/home.html). Participants learn the fundamental principles of systematic review and R programming to conduct the dataset search, result extraction, and whole transcriptome meta-analysis.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":71,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58vq4","text":"This protocol outlines the methods used during the first pilot year of the program in 2022.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"h0md","text":"This protocol provides meta-analysis guidelines and sample code, but not a full reproducible analysis pipeline and coding environment. It was meant to be adapted to the needs of each individual project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

forks.title: Brain Data Alchemy Project: Meta-Analysis of Preprocessed Public Transcriptional Profiling Data in the Gemma Database

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"eht65","text":"Any questions regarding this protocol should be directed to Dr. Megan Hagenauer (University of Michigan: hagenaue@umich.edu).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"k7k3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"udbm","text":"This protocol outlines the meta-analysis methods used by participants within the Brain Data Alchemy Program during the first pilot year of the program (2022). These methods were updated for later years - for updates, see the associated forks for this protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7tvb6","text":"The information source will be the same for all meta-analyses: The Gemma Database.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mi4k","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bot00","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"742jo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"73l56","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rmkj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1deve","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e6lf","text":"We will be leveraging the efforts of the Gemma project to curate, preprocess, and re-analyze publicly-available transcriptional profiling datasets:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":34,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"27ca3","text":"https://gemma.msl.ubc.ca/home.html","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"67aql","text":"The Gemma database contains \u003e19,000 re-analyzed transcriptional profiling datasets. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d898","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"da2te","text":"Gemma performs the following data preprocessing and analysis steps: ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"lslr","text":"1) Probe alignment or read mapping is redone whenever a new genome assembly is available. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b7qn6","text":"2) Identification and removal of outlier samples. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"faaha","text":"3) Filtering out genes (rows) with minimal variance (either zero variance or \u003c70% distinct values). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b7lkc","text":"4) Batch correction: When confounded, batches are split into separate analyses. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4tms8","text":"5) Manual curation of common issues. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e9sjc","text":"6) Differential expression output from omnibus (full dataset) tests examining the effects of the primary variables of interest as well as individual statistical contrasts.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"312C1CF5283611EF9EFE0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://gemma.msl.ubc.ca/home.html"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Zoubarev A, Hamer KM, Keshav KD, McCarthy EL, Santos JR, Van Rossum T, McDonald C, Hall A, Wan X, Lim R, Gillis J, Pavlidis P","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1346457600,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bts430","guid":"5F05E153D20A41699901EF3FFD65D8CD","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Gemma: a resource for the reuse, sharing and meta-analysis of expression profiling data."}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Lim N, Tesar S, Belmadani M, Poirier-Morency G, Mancarci BO, Sicherman J, Jacobson M, Leong J, Tan P, Pavlidis P","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1613606400,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/database/baab006","guid":"B54826386D1D4C3C93B49BBF392770B4","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Curation of over 10 000 transcriptomic studies to enable data reuse."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fqf46","text":"The scope of our meta-analysis search is pre-specified below. The scope will be the same for each meta-analysis conducted using the Brain Data Alchemy analysis pipeline.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c44b9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4rlg6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4p0o3","text":"For our meta-analysis, we will only be considering:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bhhf9","text":"1) Publicly-available transcriptional profiling datasets (gene expression microarray or RNA-Sequencing) from laboratory rodents (rats, mice). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2bspk","text":"2) We will only use datasets that profiled RNA extracted from bulk tissue dissections (i.e., not from a particular cell type or small tissue subregion).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9naj4","text":"3) We will only use datasets that profiled either the full transcriptome or a large representation of the full transcriptome. We will not use datasets targeted at a particular subpopulation of transcripts (e.g., Chip-Seq, miRNA, TRAP-Seq, etc).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dnpfr","text":"Choose your meta-analysis topic and primary research question.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78j0i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7i0dc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3s624","text":"Not all topics or research questions have been studied extensively using brain transcriptional profiling data. At this point, before pursuing the meta-analysis further, it would be helpful to have a second researcher who is not directly involved in the project (e.g., research mentor) quickly double-check whether there appears to be datasets in the Gemma database related to the chosen topic. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bt74e","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c4bha","text":"This quick, initial review should only use a handful of the most basic search terms for the topic. It is often advisable to wait to specify the tissue of interest (e.g., brain region) until later after you have determined how many the available datasets will survive the initial inclusion/exclusion criteria (protocol section 5). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"470ra","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aqbgc","text":"The 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project chose to examine the effects of chronic stress, sleep deprivation or sleep restriction, antidepressant treatment, lipopolysaccharide exposure, and viral encephalitis.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Specification of Tissue of Interest (If Not Pre-Specified)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4k1gg","text":"If a particular tissue or brain region of interest (ROI) had not been pre-specified in the search criteria, the research question should now be narrowed to a particular tissue or brain ROI based on dataset availability, and the dataset records filtered accordingly. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"181i5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ti8b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"592nr","text":"At this point, since the titles and abstracts for the datasets have already been viewed, it is important to run decisions about tissue/ROI definition past a second researcher who is less invested in the project (e.g., a research mentor) to guard against bias. These decisions may include whether to include datasets from samples that only focus on a subregion of the larger ROI, or whether to include tissue cultures as well as fresh-collected tissue.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"585t8","text":"This is a critical step. Following this initial filtering by the individual experimenter, all inclusion/exclusion choices should be reviewed and approved by a second researcher (such as a research mentor). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6mkfp","text":"The titles, abstracts, and metadata for the datasets should then be scanned to determine which datasets should be excluded based on our pre-specified criteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56gt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bi74v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7hr2t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"79eul","text":"Pre-specified exclusion criteria:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fk2jq","text":"1) Brain tissue was not collected. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ai4ep","text":"2) The experimental manipulation was unrelated to the meta-analysis topic. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"92ek7","text":"3) The brain tissue used in the experiment was not from a bulk dissection, and instead represented a particular cell type or small subregion. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"efv27","text":"4) The experiment targeted a particular subpopulation of transcripts (e.g., Chip-Seq, miRNA, TRAP-Seq, etc.).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c0hkr","text":"5) The experiment used subjects from a developmental stage other than the timeframe of interest.\n6) The metadata record on Gemma has critical issues, including duplication/overlap with another record or critical missing information (minimal methodological information due to no associated publication and a minimalist metadata record).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dnn6n","text":"Export the data frame containing the remaining metadata records from R as a .csv file. This data frame of metadata can then be more easily explored and annotated in a spreadsheet software program like Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":86,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6g14c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1iv87","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2qgui","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example R code: Writing out metadata records as a .csv file","description":"","guid":"9F9829205F2C11EF913E0A58A9FEAC02","name":"write.csv(unique_combined, \"Metadata_forDatasets_toReview.csv\")","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"80g81","text":"The metadata records should be filtered using pre-specified inclusion and exclusion criteria.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Secondary Dataset Filtering Using Detailed Methodological Review
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"epg8d","text":"The remaining dataset metadata records should now be subjected to a detailed review of accompanying experimental methods and available file formats. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5stfi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a59kf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b4206","text":"For this level of filtering, the publications associated with the datasets need to be referenced in addition to the metadata available on Gemma. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"als9l","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3qghb","text":"Only the methodological information in the publication and Gemma record should be used to determine study/dataset inclusion/exclusion, because we want our inclusion/exclusion criteria to be independent of the results reported in the original publication as much as possible. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8dsau","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f38ua","text":"Ideally, this would mean that only the methods section of the publication (or supplementary methods) would be read in depth. However, sometimes it is necessary to reference other sections of the paper in order to interpret or locate methodological information. For example, it may be necessary to read the introduction to understand the terminology and abbreviations used in the paper. Likewise, sometimes the experimental design will be overviewed in a figure, or final quality control decisions (and final sample sizes) discussed at the beginning of the results section or in the figure legends. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9iba","text":"When reviewing the methodological information in the publications and metadata for the datasets, studies should be excluded using pre-specified inclusion/exclusion criteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cth7d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8mjq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8et3f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"18usd","text":"Pre-specified inclusion/exclusion criteria:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7084s","text":"1) The study was retracted. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4iua2","text":"2) The experimental design was confounded or lacked a proper control group for the experimental manipulation of interest.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7895o","text":"3) The subjects or protocol used in the study were dramatically different from all other included datasets.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6rje5","text":"Depending on the research topic, other inclusion/exclusion criteria may also be applied. Ideally, these criteria should be pre-specified as much as possible. If not pre-specified, this deviation from the planned protocol should be reported. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5h1d8","text":"Following this secondary filtering by the individual experimenter, the experimental design for the remaining datasets and inclusion/exclusion choices should be reviewed and approved by a second researcher (such as a research mentor). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eckhl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6kq0h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"14j8d","text":"Since this is a critical step, feedback is important. For the 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, these inclusion/exclusion decisions were reviewed by the mentor and whole cohort.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1geib","text":"When reviewing the available file formats, studies should be excluded using pre-specified criteria.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dpqu0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"32j2a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a9he0","text":"Pre-specified exclusion criteria:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"qrtf","text":"1) Differential expression results are not available in Gemma for the experimental manipulation of\ninterest. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c1kho","text":"2) Differential expression results are not available in Gemma for the particular tissue or brain ROI.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3hf8d","text":"After we ran all of the meta-analyses for the Summer 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, we realized that datasets that were marked “external” in the Gemma database had sometimes been imported into Gemma in a format that was incompatible with Gemma’s analysis pipeline. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fp5l6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d02tu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7bgrh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a0ptp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":33,"offset":132}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4o1lj","text":"The analysis pipeline in Gemma typically begins with raw data extracted from public databases (e.g., Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO), https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/, (Lim et al., 2021)). After we ran all of the meta-analyses for the Summer 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, we realized that datasets that were marked “external” in the Gemma database had been subjected to a slightly different analysis pipeline. These datasets lacked available raw data, and were therefore imported into Gemma from external databases as the probe- or gene-level summarized expression data for each subject as generated by the original dataset contributors.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"atf5h","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":438,"style":"italic"},{"length":5,"offset":629,"style":"italic"},{"length":6,"offset":836,"style":"italic"}],"key":"5oj3b","text":"This imported external data sometimes appeared to be in formats that were incompatible with Gemma’s analysis pipeline. This seemed to be particularly true for datasets generated with Agilent transcriptional profiling platforms, which, for proprietary reasons, always lacked raw expression data in the GEO database, and appeared to have summarized gene expression data per sample that was generated by an unstandardized analysis pipeline (i.e., GEO records included a variety of normalization methods and formats). For these Agilent records, we regularly found that the original units in GEO were non-standard or uninterpretable (e.g., just labeled “normalized”) or had something appearing to follow a standard Log2 expression unit format but then had units within the Gemma database that had clearly been log transformed a second time (e.g., the range of Log2 expression units in Gemma was highly restricted, such as units ranging between 2-4). ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"588739A228EF11EFBC560A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Lim N, Tesar S, Belmadani M, Poirier-Morency G, Mancarci BO, Sicherman J, Jacobson M, Leong J, Tan P, Pavlidis P","can_edit":true,"created_on":"","date":1613606400,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/database/baab006","guid":"A5470EB907874D9395CD57ECA49E98A7","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_guid":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"Curation of over 10 000 transcriptomic studies to enable data reuse."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"evesf","text":"Due to these irregularities, all \"external\" datasets should be re-reviewed for evidence of irregular units at import or accidental double log2 transformation (as signaled by units with a highly restricted range - such as only ranging from 2-4). Any questionable externally-derived datasets should be excluded. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ks10","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9qfks","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":64,"style":"italic"}],"key":"488lq","text":"For the 2022 Brain Data Alchemy cohort, this exclusion happened post-hoc. After discovering these issues related to data import into Gemma, all datasets that were derived from the Agilent microarray platform and any other questionable externally-derived datasets were excluded from the 2022 meta-analyses, and the meta-analyses were re-run.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

After reading in the files from a particular dataset folder, all of the result files for that dataset should be joined together by Element_Name using the join_all() function from the plyr package.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":215,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ujug","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4nf8p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bftdv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqcsb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bf5ao","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"406dn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bndo0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"50fr9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":62,"style":"italic"}],"key":"dg5kt","text":"If this code doesn't work due to version updates, the command merge_all() can be used in a similar way.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Reading the differential expression results for a dataset downloaded from Gemma into the R environment","description":"","guid":"F4DB2C642A7F11EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"ReadingInGemmaDE<-function(ResultSetFileNames){

#Reading in the analysis results file:
TempAnalysisResults<-read.delim("analysis.results.txt", sep="\t", stringsAsFactors = FALSE, comment.char = "#")

#I placed these results in a list format:
TempResultsToJoin<-list(TempAnalysisResults)

for(i in c(1:length(ResultSetFileNames))){
#The result set files are the detailed differential expression results for a particular variable:
TempResultsToJoin[[i]]<-read.delim(ResultSetFileNames[i], sep="\t", stringsAsFactors = FALSE, comment.char = "#")
}

TempResultsJoined<<-join_all(TempResultsToJoin, by="Element_Name")
#Note: I've heard from other students that the join() and join_all() functions in the plyr package can cause problems in newer versions of R - you may need to replace this with merge and merge_all

#Saving the joined results:
write.csv(TempResultsJoined, "TempResultsJoined.csv")

rm(TempAnalysisResults, TempResultsToJoin)

print("Outputted object: TempResultsJoined")
}


#Notes about parameters for function: ReadingInGemmaDE()
#ResultSetFileNames should be a character vector containing the names of the result files, e.g., "resultset_ID478782.data.txt"","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example Usage: Reading the differential expression results for a dataset downloaded from Gemma into the R environment","description":"","guid":"DF3AA1855E6311EFB6440A58A9FEAC02","name":"#To start out with, I downloaded the Gemma differential expression output for the studies of interest.

{"blocks":[{"key":"2jtqc","text":"If gene symbol annotation is missing in the result files, additional annotation information for the transcriptional profiling platform can be downloaded from Gene Expression Omnibus. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2mt31","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"br1ii","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ptr7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6eq2v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Remove rows of data that have missing or unambiguous gene annotation","description":"","guid":"931E1BB42A8011EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"FilteringDEResults_GoodAnnotation<-function(TempResultsJoined){

print("# of rows with missing NCBI annotation:")
print(sum(TempResultsJoined$NCBI_ID==""|TempResultsJoined$NCBI_ID=="null"))

print("# of rows with missing Gene Symbol annotation:")
print(sum(TempResultsJoined$Gene_Symbol==""|TempResultsJoined$Gene_Symbol=="null"))

print("# of rows mapped to multiple NCBI_IDs:")
print(length(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined$NCBI_ID)))

print("# of rows mapped to multiple Gene Symbols:")
print(length(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined$Gene_Symbol)))

#I only want the subset of data which contains rows that do not contain a Gene Symbol of ""
TempResultsJoined_NoNA<-TempResultsJoined[(TempResultsJoined$Gene_Symbol==""|TempResultsJoined$Gene_Symbol=="null")==FALSE,]

if(length(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined_NoNA$Gene_Symbol))==0){
  TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped<<-TempResultsJoined_NoNA
}else{
#I only want rows annotated with a single Gene Symbol (no pipe):
TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped<<-TempResultsJoined_NoNA[-(grep('\\|', TempResultsJoined_NoNA$Gene_Symbol)),]
}

print("# of rows with good annotation")
print(nrow(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped))

#For record keeping (sometimes useful for troubleshooting later)
write.csv(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped, "TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped.csv")

rm(TempResultsJoined_NoNA, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped)

print("Outputted object: TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped")
}

{"blocks":[{"key":"78tio","text":"If there is more than one row of results representing the same gene symbol, the Log2FC and SE’s should be averaged for each gene symbol using the tapply() function. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":146,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gkul","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f8fm3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vvm8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"qnfk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Calculating SV and Collapsing Differential Expression Results to One Result Per Gene","description":"","guid":"327086912A8111EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"CollapsingDEResults_OneResultPerGene<-function(GSE_ID, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped, ComparisonsOfInterest, NamesOfFoldChangeColumns, NamesOfTstatColumns){
  
print("Double check that the vectors containing the two fold change and tstat column names contain the same order as the group comparisons of interest - otherwise this function won't work properly!  If the order matches, proceed:")
  
print("# of rows with unique NCBI IDs:")
print(length(unique(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$NCBI_ID)))

print("# of rows with unique Gene Symbols:")
print(length(unique(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$Gene_Symbol)))

#We will need both the Log2FC and T-stats averaged:

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_Average<-list()

for(i in c(1:length(NamesOfFoldChangeColumns))){

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_Average[[i]]<-tapply(NamesOfFoldChangeColumns[i][[1]], TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$Gene_Symbol, mean)

}

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol<-do.call(cbind, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_Average)

print("Dimensions of Fold Change matrix, averaged by gene symbol:")
print(dim(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol))

colnames(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol)<-ComparisonsOfInterest

write.csv(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol, "TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol.csv")


TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_Average<-list()

for(i in c(1:length(NamesOfFoldChangeColumns))){
  
  TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_Average[[i]]<-tapply(NamesOfTstatColumns[i][[1]], TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$Gene_Symbol, mean)
  
}

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_AveragedByGeneSymbol<-do.call(cbind, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_Average)

colnames(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_AveragedByGeneSymbol)<-ComparisonsOfInterest

write.csv(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_AveragedByGeneSymbol, "TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_AveragedByGeneSymbol.csv")



TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE<-list()

for(i in c(1:length(NamesOfFoldChangeColumns))){
  TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE[[i]]<-NamesOfFoldChangeColumns[i][[1]]/NamesOfTstatColumns[i][[1]]
}


TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_Average<-list()

for(i in c(1:length(NamesOfFoldChangeColumns))){
  
  TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_Average[[i]]<-tapply(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE[[i]], TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped$Gene_Symbol, mean)
  
}

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_AveragedByGeneSymbol<-do.call(cbind, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_Average)

colnames(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_AveragedByGeneSymbol)<-ComparisonsOfInterest

write.csv(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_AveragedByGeneSymbol, "TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_AveragedByGeneSymbol.csv")

#For running our meta-analysis, we are actually going to need the sampling variance instead of the standard error
#The sampling variance is just the standard error squared.

TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SV<-(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_AveragedByGeneSymbol)^2

write.csv(TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SV, "TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SV.csv")

TempMasterResults<-list(Log2FC=TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol, Tstat=TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_AveragedByGeneSymbol, SE=TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE_AveragedByGeneSymbol, SV=TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SV)

assign(paste("DEResults", GSE_ID, sep="_"), TempMasterResults, envir = as.environment(1))

print(paste("Output: Named DEResults", GSE_ID, sep="_"))

rm(TempMasterResults, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SV, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_SE, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_AveragedByGeneSymbol, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_FoldChange_Average, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_AveragedByGeneSymbol, TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped_Tstat_Average)

}


#Notes about parameters for function CollapsingDEResults_OneResultPerGene()
#GSE_ID is a string indicating the name of the Gemma dataset
#TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped is the data frame outputted by our previous function
#ComparisonsOfInterest is a character vector containing a list of group comparisons of interest within this dataset. Important: These group comparisons should be listed in exactly the same order as the order that you provide the column names for their associated Fold Change and Tstat output.
#NamesOfFoldChangeColumns is a list containing the columns of TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped containing the FoldChange results for your comparisons of interes, in the same order as the ComparisonsOfInterest vector
#NamesOfTstatColumns is a list containing the columns of TempResultsJoined_NoNA_NoMultimapped containing the Tstat results for your comparisons of interest, in the same order as the ComparisonsOfInterest vector

{"blocks":[{"key":"aqegb","text":"The results (Log2FC, SV) from the different statistical contrasts of interest and datasets should then be compiled into a single data frame. To do this, results can be aligned (joined) using official gene symbol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fo8ml","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"97c9c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eo5t7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1o5rb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9r7r5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5snkk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":69,"offset":140}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fcchi","text":"We are taking advantage of the fact that 75% of official gene symbols are identical in rats and mice (Jackson Labs Mouse ortholog database: https://www.informatics.jax.org/downloads/reports/HOM_AllOrganism.rpt ). ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"A71CBBB328F211EFBC560A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.informatics.jax.org/downloads/reports/HOM_AllOrganism.rpt"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Combining results from different studies into a single data frame","description":"","guid":"AC37F7472A8111EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"AligningDatasets<-function(ListOfDEResults){
  
  MetaAnalysis_FoldChange_Dfs<-list()
  
  for(i in c(1:length(ListOfDEResults))){
    MetaAnalysis_FoldChange_Dfs[[i]]<-data.frame(x=row.names(ListOfDEResults[[i]][[1]]),ListOfDEResults[[i]][[1]], stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
  }
  
  print("MetaAnalysis_FoldChange_Dfs:")
  print(str(MetaAnalysis_FoldChange_Dfs))
  
  MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges<<-join_all(MetaAnalysis_FoldChange_Dfs, by="x", type="full")
  #This function could be join_all (if there are more than 2 datasets) or merge/merge_all (if the plyr package isn't working)
  
  print("MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges:")
  print(str(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges))
  
  MetaAnalysis_SV_Dfs<-list()
  
  for(i in c(1:length(ListOfDEResults))){
    MetaAnalysis_SV_Dfs[[i]]<-data.frame(x=row.names(ListOfDEResults[[i]][[4]]),ListOfDEResults[[i]][[4]], stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
  }
  
  print("MetaAnalysis_SV_Dfs:")
  print(str(MetaAnalysis_SV_Dfs))
  
  MetaAnalysis_SV<<-join_all(MetaAnalysis_SV_Dfs, by="x", type="full")
  #This function could be join_all (if there are more than 2 datasets) or merge/merge_all (if the plyr package isn't working)
  
  print("MetaAnalysis_SV:")
  print(str(MetaAnalysis_SV))
  
  rm(MetaAnalysis_SV_Dfs, MetaAnalysis_FoldChange_Dfs)
}

#Notes on using the function:

#This function combines together the relevant results from different studies into a single data-frame for the effect sizes (Log2FC) and a single data.frame for the sampling variances. 

#The Log2FC values are the first element in the differential expression result object for each study

#The gene symbols are the row.names - 75% of gene symbols for rats and mice are the same, so for simplicity sake, instead of using a gene orthology database to inform equivalency, we're just going to align the datasets by gene symbol.
","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example Usage: Combining results from different studies into a single data frame","description":"","guid":"FE384F1E5E6511EFB6440A58A9FEAC02","name":"#Example Usage;

ListOfDEResults<-list(DEResults_GSE27532, DEResults_GSE56028, DEResults_GSE63469)

#The Log2FC values are the first element in the differential expression result object for each study
#The gene symbols are the row.names
#Make sure that the datasets don't have *comparisons with the same name*, or those comparisons disappear during the join. :(
#That can be avoided by always including the dataset name (GSE#) in the column names for the comparisons of interest

AligningDatasets(ListOfDEResults)

{"blocks":[{"key":"c0stb","text":"Because we are considering differential expression results that are derived from a variety of different transcriptional profiling platforms with varying transcript/probe representation and sensitivity, each dataset will include differential expression results for a slightly different set of genes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89e1v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8hh1k","text":"Decide on a minimum number of differential expression results that need to be present to run a meta-analysis for each gene (i.e., a minimum number of Log2FC values that are not NAs). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3qqv7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fejb6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ijaf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"hlvd","text":"This decision should be guided by considerations related to sample size and the minimum number of datasets necessary to represent the diversity of subjects and methods available in your datasets.  If you only have a small number of datasets included in your meta-analysis (\u003c5 datasets), you may want to require that a gene be represented in all of them to be included in the meta-analysis. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

It is likely to work using other versions of the package.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Viechtbauer, W","can_edit":true,"created_on":"2010-08-05","date":0,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v036.i03","guid":"C69DE1E65F3711EF913E0A58A9FEAC02","journal":"Journal of Statistical Software","protocol_guid":"","title":"Conducting meta-analyses in R with the metafor package"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"26k2a","text":"If the row (gene) meets our criteria, we use the function rma() from the metafor package to fit a random effects meta-analysis model to the Log2FC values (yi) and accompanying SV (vi).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":58,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":155,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":180,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":156,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":181,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"891at","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ispr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1cg03","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"214po","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d6na4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"kdtg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4t9jr","text":"Due to the relatively small number of differential expression results that are available for most topics, we have chosen to use the simplest model possible for the meta-analysis (an intercept-only model) as our main outcome. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"drff","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":119,"style":"italic"}],"key":"a66a0","text":"The downside to this approach is an inadequate accounting for the covariance of results derived from the same dataset (e.g., a dataset with multiple drug treatments compared to a control treatment). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ecdcg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9mmua","text":"This approach also means that we do not attempt to quantify potentially impactful sources of
heterogeneity within the subject characteristics or methodology of the studies. If there is a larger number of datasets (e.g., 4-5 datasets representing each of the potential sources of heterogeneity), it may be worth exploring models including these variables as secondary
outcomes.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Running a meta-analysis on the data frame of differential expression results","description":"","guid":"F5A1845F2A8211EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"RunBasicMetaAnalysis<-function(NumberOfComparisons, CutOffForNAs, MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges, MetaAnalysis_SV){
  
  MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<-apply(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges, 1, function(y) sum(is.na(y)))
  
  print("Table of # of NAs per Row (Gene):")
  print(table(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow))
  
  MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta<<-MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges[MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<CutOffForNAs,]
  MetaAnalysis_SV_ForMeta<<-MetaAnalysis_SV[MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<CutOffForNAs,]
  
  print("MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta:")
  print(str(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta))
  
  #I'm going to make an empty matrix to store the results of my meta-analysis:
  metaOutput<-matrix(NA, length(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta$x), 6)
  
  #And then run a loop that run's a meta-analysis on the differential expression results (columns 2-10) for each gene (row):
  for(i in c(1:length(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta$x))){
    
    effect<-as.numeric(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta[i,-1])
    var<-as.numeric(MetaAnalysis_SV_ForMeta[i,-1])
    
    #I added a function tryCatch that double-checks that the meta-analysis function (rma) doesn't produce errors (which breaks the loop):
    skip_to_next <- FALSE
    tryCatch(TempMeta<-rma(effect, var), error = function(e) {skip_to_next <<- TRUE})
    
    if(skip_to_next){}else{
      TempMeta<-rma(effect, var)
      metaOutput[i, 1]<-TempMeta$b #gives estimate Log2FC
      metaOutput[i, 2]<-TempMeta$se #gives standard error
      metaOutput[i, 3]<-TempMeta$pval #gives pval
      metaOutput[i, 4]<-TempMeta$ci.lb #gives confidence interval lower bound
      metaOutput[i, 5]<-TempMeta$ci.ub #gives confidence interval upper bound
      metaOutput[i, 6]<-NumberOfComparisons-sum(is.na(effect))#Number of comparisons with data
      rm(TempMeta)
    }
    rm(effect, var)
  }
  
  colnames(metaOutput)<-c("Log2FC_estimate", "SE", "pval", "CI_lb", "CI_ub", "Number_Of_Comparisons")
  row.names(metaOutput)<-MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta$x
  
  metaOutput<<-metaOutput
  return(metaOutput)
  
  print("metaOutput:")
  print(str(metaOutput))
  
  print("Top of metaOutput:")
  print(head(metaOutput))
  
  print("Bottom of metaOutput")
  print(tail(metaOutput))
  
}
","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example Usage: Running a meta-analysis on the data frame of differential expression results","description":"","guid":"AC89C1FD5E6611EFB6440A58A9FEAC02","name":"#We can only run a meta-analysis if there are differential expression results from more than one comparison.
#Since I know that the differential expression results from the same study (dataset) are artificially correlated, I would actually prefer that there are results from more than one dataset.

#How many genes satisfy this criteria?

#This code calculates the number of NAs in each row:
MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow<-apply(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges, 1, function(y) sum(is.na(y)))

#I'm going to make a histogram of the results because I'm curious to see how they are distributed
hist(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow)

#Or, since there are a limited number of integer answers (0-11), I could make a table of the results:
table(MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow)
#MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow
MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow
# 0     1     2     3     4     5     6 
# 11562  1356   496  2310  2886  2728  1434  

#Let's try running a meta-analysis using genes that were found in at least 7 sets of differential expression results
#Since there are 7 sets of differential expression results, that means that the genes that we are including need to have 0 or fewer NAs in their results
#I set this conservatively, because there are so few studies in this meta-analysis.
#1 NAs is too many

#Example Usage:
NumberOfComparisons=7
CutOffForNAs=1
#I want at least 7 comparisons
#1 NA is too many

metaOutput<-RunBasicMetaAnalysis(NumberOfComparisons, CutOffForNAs, MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges, MetaAnalysis_SV)
#Note: this function can take a while to run, especially if you have a lot of data  
#Plug in your computer, take a break, grab some coffee...

# [1] "Table of # of NAs per Row (Gene):"
# MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_NAsPerRow
# 0     1     2     3     4     5     6 
# 11562  1356   496  2310  2886  2728  1434 
# [1] "MetaAnalysis_FoldChanges_ForMeta:"
# 'data.frame':	11562 obs. of  8 variables:
#   $ x                            : chr  "A4galt" "Aaas" "Aacs" "Aadac" ...

# $ Fluoxetine_10mgPerKg_vs_Ctrl : num  -0.06863 -0.00253 -0.01577 -0.1021 0.1074 ...
# $ Imipramine_10mgPerKg_vs_Ctrl : num  -0.0039 -0.0874 -0.1441 -0.1393 0.00518 ...
# $ Venlafaxine_30kgDkg_vs_Ctrl  : num  0.2085 0.1111 -0.0447 -0.1497 -0.0331 ...

#Example Output:

str(metaOutput)
# num [1:11562, 1:6] 0.06022 -0.01543 -0.06567 -0.07498 -0.00186 ...

{"blocks":[{"key":"8v7n","text":"We correct the p-values for false discovery rate (FDR) using the the Benjamini-Hochberg method as applied by the mt.rawp2adjp() function within the multtest package.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":113,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqeh2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2138r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"floaa","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eodpc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"R Function: Applying an FDR correction to meta-analysis p-values","description":"","guid":"359B3BA92A8311EF85500A58A9FEAC02","name":"FalseDiscoveryCorrection<-function(metaOutput){
  
  tempPvalAdjMeta<-mt.rawp2adjp(metaOutput[,3], proc=c("BH"))
  
  metaPvalAdj<-tempPvalAdjMeta$adjp[order(tempPvalAdjMeta$index),]
  
  metaOutputFDR<-cbind(metaOutput, metaPvalAdj[,2])
  
  colnames(metaOutputFDR)[7]<-"FDR"
  
  metaOutputFDR<<-metaOutputFDR
  
  print("metaOutputFDR:")
  print(str(metaOutputFDR))
  
  write.csv(metaOutputFDR, "metaOutputFDR.csv")
  
  #a version of the output in order by p-value:
  metaOutputFDR_OrderbyPval<<-metaOutputFDR[order(metaOutputFDR[,3]),]
  
  #Let's write out a version of the output in order by p-value:
  write.csv(metaOutputFDR_OrderbyPval, "metaOutputFDR_orderedByPval_wHDRFData.csv")
  
  print("Do we have any genes that are statistically significant following false discovery rate correction?")
  print(sum(metaOutputFDR[,7]<0.10, na.rm=TRUE))
  
  print("What are the top results?")
  print(head(metaOutputFDR[order(metaOutputFDR[,3]),]))
  
  rm(tempPvalAdjMeta, metaPvalAdj)
  
}
","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"Example usage: Applying an FDR correction to meta-analysis p-values","description":"","guid":"1D5D12665E6711EF862F0A58A9FEAC02","name":"#Example usage:

FalseDiscoveryCorrection(metaOutput)

steps.section: Applying a False Discovery Rate (FDR) Correction to the Meta-Analysis Results
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dqu0c","text":"We will consider results to be statistically significant if they survive a threshold of 5% false discovery (FDR\u003c0.05). If our meta-analyses do not produce any results surviving this threshold, we may consider results at a weaker threshold (FDR\u003c0.10) with the understanding that a higher percent of these results are likely to be false discovery (10%).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"210i2","text":"To explore our meta-analysis results, we first rank the results by p-value and examine the results surviving our false discovery rate correction (FDR\u003c0.05). We will refer to these results as our \"top genes\".","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4qqm6","text":"Within the results surviving false discovery rate correction, count how many show increased expression (\"upregulation\") in response to our variable of interest and how many show decreased expression (\"down-regulation\"). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fcbv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1rsvu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c6j70","text":"Within the meta-analysis results, a negative \"estimate\" (estimated Log2FC) means that the gene typically shows lower expression in response to our variable of interest, whereas a positive estimate (estimated Log2FC) means that a gene typically shows higher expression in response to our variable of interest.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

running functional ontology analyses on differential expression results from brain tissue, it is particularly important to either use a tool that either considers the full ranked list of results (i.e., all significant (FDR\u003c0.05) and non-significant results) or that compares the significant results (FDR\u003c0.05) to a \"background\" of all genes contained within the results. Do not use the full genome as the \"background\" for your functional comparison. Only a subset of the genome is expressed in brain tissue - therefore, by definition, the genes included in your results are already enriched for brain functions, regardless of their relationship to your variable of interest. {"blocks":[{"key":"c47jq","text":"For the sake of easily including results from the project in future posters, presentations and publications, we have a template for quickly summarizing meta-analysis results.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2fc3a","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7t0f1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5rnv7","text":"A Google Docs template for quickly illustrating and summarizing the meta-analysis results can be found here:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":135,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"as0mi","text":"https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1fAirnPu9zdu4uHRIuESeK5RTDxwFqiD8/edit?usp=sharing\u0026ouid=106595687423493776462\u0026rtpof=true\u0026sd=true","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"F7379B462AB111EF83D90A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1fAirnPu9zdu4uHRIuESeK5RTDxwFqiD8/edit?usp=sharing\u0026ouid=106595687423493776462\u0026rtpof=true\u0026sd=true"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b9i74","text":"In order to wrap up the meta-analysis project in a manner that can be easily followed up on later by yourself or others, it is important to preserve input, output, code, and workspaces.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9t88s","text":"To preserve and share code, it is useful to upload the final R code and workspaces to a Github repository.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1f5lu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"25ilo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ask78","text":"Here are instructions for initiating a Github repository:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":102,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dq303","text":"https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/quickstart-for-repositories","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"am5lg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"csgr3","text":"(if you haven't already been using Github for version control throughout the duration of the project)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"395590AF5E6811EF862F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/quickstart-for-repositories"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"87nna","text":"First, make sure that you save both your code and workspace in R. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1nl2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86u7i","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"42qme","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6n35u","text":"The names for the code files will end with the file extension \".R\". ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3n57f","text":"The names for the workspace files will end with the file extension \".Rdata\".","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2rkjk","text":"To make your analyses reproducible, make sure that you save the folders containing the Gemma differential expression results for each dataset that you used as input for your meta-analysis. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tev2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b7tj0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7hfld","text":"Gemma updates gene annotation each time a new genome assembly is released, therefore a scientist following the same extraction and analysis procedure a year from now might get different results if they do not have your exact input.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"17ror","text":"In addition to your PRISMA search diagram, table of final datasets, and results summary, make sure to save the full meta-analysis results for all genes. The full results can be provided as a supplementary table in a publication.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9tg29","text":"A README describing the organization for all of the meta-analysis files can help you (or others) navigate the files later.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f62da","text":"Examine the search terms more carefully and specify the formal search syntax.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1lg2s","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7bho8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6mjs7","text":"We will be conducting our dataset search using an R coding package that accesses the API (application programming interface) for the Gemma database. Gemma's API uses formal search syntax (i.e., search term construction). This syntax is not as flexible (or smart!) as a Google search, and differs in some ways from more conventional databases such as PubMed or Embase.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"54cav","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9p7s2","text":"Examine your search terms carefully to define your formal syntax:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a1ucc","text":"Are there a variety of potential endings for any of the terms? (e.g., \"stress\" vs. \"stressful\" vs. \"stressed\" vs. \"stressing\") If so, you may be able to just include the shared component of the term with an asterisk to indicate term expansion (e.g., \"stress*\")","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"31ahu","text":"Are any of these terms likely to identify datasets that are not related to your topic? If so, you might want to rule them out with NOT, e.g., \"stress* NOT distress\")","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6h6t","text":"If you have a term that is a phrase that includes more than one word, you may need to add quotations around that phrase if the exact phrase is desired/necessary (\"chronic social defeat stress\"). Or, if you need two or more words in your phrase to be present, but the exact order/spacing is not important, you can use AND (e.g., \"chronic AND social AND stress\").","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"62fev","text":"Independent search terms can be combined into a longer list using OR (e.g., \"stress* OR advers* \")","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6vpuq","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7rj9o","text":"Defining search syntax is also a critical step, and feedback is important. For the 2022 cohort of the Brain Data Alchemy Project, these terms were reviewed by the mentor.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Applying a False Discovery Rate (FDR) Correction to the Meta-Analysis Results
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"i42q","text":"False Discovery Rate Correction: Since we have run meta-analyses for thousands of genes, we correct the p-values for false discovery rate (FDR) using the the Benjamini-Hochberg method. This coding is all performed within the R environment using Rstudio.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pflq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fr7v8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c2ucl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b1gu5","text":"To properly interpret the p-values produced by our meta-analyses for each gene, we need to take into account the fact that we have run thousands of statistical tests (i.e., one statistical test for each gene for thousands of genes). Therefore, we are likely to get a large number of results that are \"significant\" using a traditional p-value threshold (alpha=0.05) just due to random chance. This is called a multiple comparisons correction or p-value adjustment. We use a type of correction called False Discovery Rate (FDR) or q-value. It is also sometimes called a \"Benjamini–Hochberg\" adjustment after its originators.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
